titleStmt.title: National Library of Sweden, A 68
titleStmt.sponsor: Medieval Latin Manuscripts in the National Library: Cataloguing and Digitization
titleStmt.funder: Riksbankens jubileumsfond â€“ The Swedish Foundation for Humanities and Social Sciences

publicationStmt.publisher: manuscripta.se: A Digital Catalogue of Medieval and Early Modern Manuscripts in Sweden

msDesc.head: St. Birgitta, Revelations; Simon of Cascia; Bernhardinus of Siena; Richard Rolle of Hampole, De emendatione peccatorum; Theological texts; Ars Moriendi

binding.p: Rebound with new flyleaves in 1979. Put in a loose cover with broad support bands. The volume was formerly bound in 16th-century covers, which originally belonged to a different work, and was not related to the contents of the manuscript. The old 16th-century covers are kept in a separate box.

history.origin:
Germany
15th century, second half. The watermarks support a dating to ca 1470.
history.acquisition: Purchased by the National Library on 14 February 1918 in Fritzes bokhandel (bookstore) Stockholm.

msItem.title: Revelations
Revelations, Book I.20-22; I.45-60
msItem.incipit: multis pro futuro Sicut enim surculus si inseritur trunco arido truncus incipit florere

msItem.title: Revelations, Book II
msItem.rubric: Verba beate brigitte ad christum quare non subtrahat malos antequam veniant ad peccatum. Secundus liber celestium reuelacionum beate brigitte
msItem.explicit: non est licitum tibi scire Sed cum tempus fuerit loquendi

msItem.title: Revelations, Book VIII
msItem.explicit: quod ego sum suauis et mitis

msItem.title: Revelations, Book III
msItem.incipit: Ihesus christus deus et homo qui venit in terram assumere humanitatem
msItem.explicit: ut verba Dei per illud diffundantur

msItem.title: Revelations, Book IV
msItem.explicit: qui cottidie festinanter appropinquant gracie et visioni maiestatis
msItem.note: On the words "Explicit quartus liber" followed by a note in pencil by Collijn.

msItem.title: Sermo Angelicus
msItem.incipit: Cum beata brigitta principissa regni swecie
msItem.explicit: et regnat deus in secula seculorum Amen

msItem.title: Revelations, Book V
msItem.incipit: Incipit quintus liber celestium reuelacionum Christi ad beatam Brigittam.
msItem.explicit: Itaque cum veneris ad ista loca ostendam tibi plura etc

msItem.title: Revelations, Book VI
msItem.incipit: Mater dei loquebatur ad sponsam dicens ego sum regina celi
msItem.explicit: Ideo dimittatur proprie voluntati, quia deo accepcius est in mundo iuste viuere et laborare manibus quam in heremo uel religione stare sine dei caritate etc

msItem.title: Revelations, Book VII
msItem.incipit: Iste liber celestium reuelacionum est ultimus et has reuelaciones huius libri habuit domina Brigitta in Roma
msItem.explicit: Dicta vero missa et sacramentis perceptis cum maxima deuocione et reuerencia inter manus dictarum personarum emisit spiritum. Feliciter finitum anno domini 1372.

note.p: The year 1372 in the explicit corrected from 1472.

msItem.title: Excerpts from the Revelations, books IV and VI

msItem.note: The chapter numbers generally differ somewhat from modern editions.

msItem.title: Excerpts from texts by Simon of Cascia and Bernardinus of Siena
msItem.explicit: qui autem in terra posuerit uel positum non leuauerit morte mulcetur

msItem.title: Richard Rolle of Hampole, De emendatione peccatorum
msItem.incipit: Ne tardes conuerti ad dominum et ne deferas de die in diem
msItem.explicit: Cui sit honor et gloria et graciarumactio in secula seculorum Amen

msItem.title: Theological tractate
msItem.explicit: in quo Christus cenauit cum discipulis

msItem.title: Ars Moriendi QS
msItem.incipit: Quamuis secundum philosophum 3o ethicorum omnium terribilium mors corporis sit terribilissima
msItem.note: This is the version called Ars Moriendi QS after the first words Quamvis secundum. The texts ends on with a passage rubricated Oracio depassione

watermark.term: Head of bull with flower (closest to Briquet 14856).
Two keys with cross (closest to Briquet 3883)
Head of bull with flower (closest to Briquet 14857)
Head of bull with crown and flower (closest to Piccard II:3, p. 737, nr 360).
Head of bull with flower and snake (closest to Piccard II:3, p. 623, nr 649).
Head of bull with flower (closest to Piccard II:3, p. 668, nr 213).

p.note: On watermarks in this manuscript, see Spahl (2009), De emendatione vitae

supportDesc.foliation: Contemporary foliation . Several leaves are missing at the beginning; the foliation starts at â€¯â€¯, followed by â€¯â€¯; â€¯â€¯ is doubled.
supportDesc.condition: Some folios are worn, especially at the beginning and at the end.

handDesc.handNote: Gothic cursive. Possibly another hand on . Capitals touched with red. Chapter numbers and some rubrics in lighter red ink.

p.note: Several notes in pencil, probably by Isak Collijn.
The words Oracio beate Brigitte and a pointing hand in the margin.

decoDesc.decoNote: Larger initials in red of about 5 lines.
